github_mcp_tools_usage.overview:
The GitHub MCP server provides multiple tools for interacting with GitHub. Here's when and how to use each tool in the issue creation workflow.
Note: Issue body formatting should follow the templates defined in and

tool.name: search_issues
tool.when_to_use: ALWAYS use this FIRST before creating any issue to check for duplicates. Search for keywords from the user's problem description.

tool.name: list_issues
tool.when_to_use: Use to browse recent issues if search doesn't find specific matches. Helpful for understanding issue patterns and formatting.

tool.name: get_issue
tool.when_to_use: Use when you find a potentially related issue and need full details. Check if the user's issue is already reported or related.

tool.name: get_issue_comments
tool.when_to_use: Use on related issues to understand discussion context. Helps avoid creating issues for already-discussed topics.

tool.name: list_commits
tool.when_to_use: For bug reports, check recent commits that might have introduced the issue. Look for commits touching the affected files.

tool.name: get_commit
tool.when_to_use: When you identify a potentially problematic commit. Get details about what changed.

tool.name: search_code
tool.when_to_use: Use to find code patterns across the repository on GitHub. Complements local codebase_search tool.

tool.name: list_pull_requests
tool.when_to_use: Check recent PRs that might be related to the issue. Look for PRs that modified relevant code.

tool.name: create_issue
tool.when_to_use: Only use after: 1. Confirming no duplicates exist 2. Gathering all required information per or 3. Exploring codebase for context 4. Getting user confirmation

use_mcp_tool.arguments: { "owner": "RooCodeInc", "repo": "Roo-Code", "title": "[Descriptive title of the bug]", "body": "[Format according to fields]", "labels": ["bug"] }
{ "owner": "RooCodeInc", "repo": "Roo-Code", "title": "[Descriptive title of the feature request]", "body": "[Format according to fields]", "labels": ["proposal", "enhancement"] }

tool.name: add_issue_comment
tool.when_to_use: Use if user wants to add additional information after creation. Also use to link related issues.

tool.name: update_issue
tool.when_to_use: Use if user realizes they need to update the issue after creation. Can update title, body, or state.

use_mcp_tool.arguments: { "owner": "RooCodeInc", "repo": "Roo-Code", "issue_number": 456, "title": "[Updated title if needed]", "body": "[Updated body if needed]" }

workflow_integration.step_1_integration: After user selects issue type, immediately search for related issues: 1. Use search_issues with keywords from their description 2. Show any similar issues found 3. Ask if they want to continue or comment on existing issue
workflow_integration.step_3_integration: When searching GitHub Discussions: 1. Note that GitHub MCP tools don't currently support discussions API 2. Instruct user to manually search discussions at: https://github.com/RooCodeInc/Roo-Code/discussions/categories/feature-requests 3. Ask user to provide any related discussion numbers they find 4. Include these in the "Related Discussions" section of the issue
workflow_integration.step_4_integration: During codebase exploration: 1. Use list_commits to find recent changes to affected files 2. Use search_code for additional code references 3. Check list_pull_requests for related PRs 4. Include findings in the technical context section
workflow_integration.step_5_integration: When creating the issue: 1. Format the issue body according to or 2. Use create_issue with complete formatted body 3. Capture the returned issue number 4. If related issues were found, use add_issue_comment to link them 5. Show user the created issue URL

error_handling.duplicate_found: If search_issues finds exact duplicate: - Show the existing issue to user - Ask if they want to add a comment instead - Use add_issue_comment if they agree
error_handling.creation_failed: If create_issue fails: - Check error message (permissions, rate limit, etc.) - Save the drafted issue content - Provide user with the content to create manually
error_handling.api_limits: Be aware of GitHub API rate limits: - Authenticated requests: 5000/hour - Search API: 30 requests/minute - Use searches efficiently
